headline.print_headline: Playing Politics? Chinese Tourism Under Scrutiny as Lunar New Year Nears
headline.main: Playing Politics? Chinese Tourism Under Scrutiny as Lunar New Year Nears

docs.lead_paragraph: With 6 million Chinese tourists expected to travel abroad over the Lunar New Year break, China's Jan. 27 to Feb. 2 holiday is crucial for Taiwan tour agency operator Li Chi-yueh, who relies on mainland visitors for a third of his revenue.
docs.snippet: With 6 million Chinese tourists expected to travel abroad over the Lunar New Year break, China's Jan. 27 to Feb. 2 holiday is crucial for Taiwan tour agency operator Li Chi-yueh, who relies on mainland visitors for a third of his revenue....

headline.main: Traveling with a Smaller Carbon Footprint

docs.abstract: A great deal of leisure tourism, which relies on natural features like snow-covered mountains or sunny beaches, is dependent on the weather, making it one of the one of the most climate-sensitive economic sectors.

headline.main: Bronx Journal; Pitching for Tourists (and Not Just Yankee Fans)

docs.lead_paragraph: It was a distinctly unurban scene: Two carriages hauled by huge Belgian draft horses stopped at a sea wall overlooking Long Island Sound. A carriage driver in a bright red sweater dropped the reins and called out to a group of somewhat skeptical guests waiting for him. "Welcome, everybody," the driver, 42-year-old Michael Sandlofer, said. "Welcome to the Bronx."

headline.main: ROUTE OF L.I. NUCLEAR WASTE IS ARGUED AT HOUSE HEARING

docs.lead_paragraph: Representatives from New York City and Connecticut clashed today over proposals for routing shipments of nuclear waste generated at Long Island's Brookhaven Laboratory. While most of the Congressmen conceded the debate was parochial, they said it highlighted the need for changes in current Federal regulations of nuclear-waste transport. The hearings, before the Subcommittee on Commerce, Transportation and Tourism, renewed arguments in the eight-year-old attempt by New York City to block Federal plans to transport nuclear waste from the laboratory through the city on its way to temporary repositories in Idaho.

byline.original: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to the New York Times

keywords.value: HOUSE SUBCOMMITTEE ON COMMERCE AND TOURISM
keywords.name: organizations
